questions.text: A female patient presents with swollen Bartholin glands. Discharging pus showed Gram-negative intracellular diplococci. Which is the organism? (INICET MAY 2024)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Neisseria gonorrhoeae

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Neisseria gonorrhoeae, a Gram-negative intracellular diplococcus, is the causative agent of gonorrhea and can infect the Bartholin glands, leading to swelling and pus discharge.

questions.text: A blood spill in the operation theatre must be cleaned with? (INICET MAY 2017)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Chlorine compound

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For cleaning a blood spill in the operation theatre, sodium hypochlorite, a chlorine compound, is the best disinfectant due to its effectiveness in inactivating a wide range of pathogens and its suitability for such critical environments.

questions.text: A patient presents with itching in the axilla. On microscopic examination of the skin scrapings, a red pigment-producing fungus with pencil-shaped macroconidia is seen. Which of the following is the most likely organism? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Trichophyton rubrum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Trichophyton rubrum is identified by its red pigment-producing, velvety colonies with characteristic pencil-shaped macroconidia, making it the causative agent of various dermatophyte infections including tinea corporis that could present with itching in the axilla. Understanding the colony morphology and microscopic features is crucial for accurate identification and appropriate treatment of dermatophyte infections.

questions.text: A patient with benign prostatic hyperplasia (BPH), who has had a urinary catheter in place for three weeks, presents with signs and symptoms suggestive of a catheter-associated urinary tract infection (CAUTI). The catheter tip is sent for culture on blood agar. After 24 hours, the culture displays a unique swarming growth pattern. Which of the following microorganisms is the most likely cause of this infection? (AIIMS NOV 2016)
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Proteus mirabilis is a gram-negative bacterium known for its characteristic "swarming" motility on solid media, such as blood agar. This swarming pattern is due to the bacteria's peritrichous flagella, which allow for rapid and coordinated movement across the agar surface. This unique motility pattern, combined with the patient's clinical history (BPH and long-term catheterization), strongly suggests Proteus mirabilis as the causative agent of the CAUTI.
  • • Other Options :
  • • Other Options
  • • Option A. Escherichia coli : While E. coli is a common cause of UTIs, it does not exhibit the characteristic swarming motility seen on blood agar. Option B. Klebsiella pneumoniae : K. pneumoniae is another common UTI pathogen, but it typically forms mucoid colonies and does not swarm on blood agar. Option D. Pseudomonas aeruginosa : P. aeruginosa is a less common cause of CAUTIs and typically produces pigmented colonies with a distinct odor. It does not exhibit swarming motility.
  • • Option A. Escherichia coli : While E. coli is a common cause of UTIs, it does not exhibit the characteristic swarming motility seen on blood agar.
  • • Option A. Escherichia coli
  • • Option B. Klebsiella pneumoniae : K. pneumoniae is another common UTI pathogen, but it typically forms mucoid colonies and does not swarm on blood agar.
  • • Option B. Klebsiella pneumoniae
  • • Option D. Pseudomonas aeruginosa : P. aeruginosa is a less common cause of CAUTIs and typically produces pigmented colonies with a distinct odor. It does not exhibit swarming motility.
  • • Option D. Pseudomonas aeruginosa

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The presence of swarming motility on blood agar is a hallmark of Proteus mirabilis and is a strong indicator of this organism as the causative agent in cases of suspected catheter-associated urinary tract infections.

questions.text: The microorganism demonstrates resistance to meropenem and aminoglycosides, while being susceptible to ticarcillin-clavulanate and cotrimoxazole. Which microorganism is most likely responsible? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Stenotrophomonas maltophila

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Stenotrophomonas maltophila is an opportunistic pathogen resistant to meropenem and aminoglycosides but susceptible to ticarcillin-clavulanate and cotrimoxazole.

questions.text: What is the incubation period of lymphogranuloma venereum? (INICET MAY 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) 10-30 days

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The incubation period of lymphogranuloma venereum (LGV) is 10-30 days. It is caused by Chlamydia trachomatis serovars L1, L2, and L3, and primarily affects the lymphatic system. Diagnosis is based on serological tests or identification of the bacteria in clinical specimens through various methods.

questions.text: Which of the following is classified under Biosafety level -3 infections? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) XDR-TB

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • XDR-TB (Extensively Drug-Resistant Tuberculosis) requires BSL-3 (Biosafety Level 3) containment due to its high risk of airborne transmission and severe disease potential.
  • • Other Options :
  • • Other Options
  • • Option B. Salmonella : Generally handled under BSL-2 due to lower risk.
  • • Option B. Salmonella
  • • Option C. Ebola : Handled under BSL-4, given its high risk and lethality.
  • • Option C. Ebola
  • • Option D. Congo Crimean Fever : Also requires BSL-4 due to high fatality rates and transmission risk.
  • • Option D. Congo Crimean Fever

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The classification of pathogens is according to biosafety levels. XDR-TB is managed under BSL-3 conditions due to its airborne risks and drug resistance challenges.

questions.text: A 32-year-old pregnant woman presents to her obstetrician for a routine check-up. She reports mild flu-like symptoms, including low-grade fever, muscle aches, and fatigue over the past week. She mentions that she has recently been cleaning her cat’s litter box frequently. Given her symptoms and history, the physician considers the risk of a particular parasitic infection. Based on the lifecycle depicted in the image below, identify the organism responsible for her condition.
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The image depicts the lifecycle of Toxoplasma gondii, an obligate intracellular parasite that causes toxoplasmosis. Cats, members of the Felidae family, are the definitive hosts where the enteric cycle occurs. The parasite's lifecycle involves the shedding of unsporulated oocysts in cat feces, which become infective within 1-5 days. Intermediate hosts, including humans, birds, and rodents, become infected upon ingestion of sporulated oocysts from contaminated environments. In humans, T. gondii can form tissue cysts in various organs, such as muscle and brain, which may remain latent throughout life. This infection can be particularly concerning during pregnancy due to the risk of transplacental transmission to the fetus.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Plasmodium falciparum : This parasite causes malaria and is transmitted by Anopheles mosquitoes. Its lifecycle primarily involves humans and mosquitoes, not involving cats or fecal-oral transmission, making it unrelated to the lifecycle depicted.
  • • Option A. Plasmodium falciparum
  • • Option C. Giardia lamblia : Giardia causes gastrointestinal infections, primarily spread through contaminated water and food. It does not involve a definitive feline host or a lifecycle involving oocysts, as seen in Toxoplasma gondii.
  • • Option C. Giardia lamblia
  • • Option D. Entamoeba histolytica : This parasite causes amebiasis, leading to dysentery and liver abscesses, primarily through the fecal-oral route involving contaminated water. Its lifecycle does not involve cats or the formation of tissue cysts as seen with Toxoplasma gondii.
  • • Option D. Entamoeba histolytica

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Toxoplasma gondii is an obligate intracellular parasite with a lifecycle involving definitive feline hosts and intermediate hosts, including humans. Transmission occurs through ingestion of sporulated oocysts from contaminated sources or undercooked meat. Infections can be particularly dangerous during pregnancy, leading to transplacental transmission and congenital toxoplasmosis.

questions.text: A patient presents with seizures. His CT head reveals multiple parenchymal cysts. Which of the following is correct regarding management in this case? (INICET NOV 2020)
questions.correct_answer: A. Steroids followed by antiparasitic drugs
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Steroids followed by antiparasitic drugs

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The management of neurocysticercosis involves administering steroids first to control inflammation, followed by antiparasitic drugs to target the larval infection, along with antiepileptic drugs to control seizures.

questions.text: A food safety inspector is reviewing the pasteurization process at a dairy that has been linked to a recent outbreak of milk-borne illness. During the inspection, he asks the technical staff, "At what temperature and duration is pasteurization typically performed to ensure the safety of milk without significantly altering its taste and nutritional value?"
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The correct answer is the Holder method of pasteurization, where milk is heated to 63°C for 30 minutes. This method effectively kills most non-spore-forming pathogens, making milk safe for consumption while preserving its nutritional and sensory qualities. Pasteurization generally involves heating milk at specific temperatures: either 63°C for 30 minutes (Holder method) or 72°C for 15-20 seconds (flash pasteurization). After heating, the milk is rapidly cooled to 13°C or lower to inhibit bacterial growth. These processes eliminate nearly all harmful bacteria, though some heat-resistant organisms like Coxiella burnetti may survive the Holder method. This approach ensures the safety of milk without significantly altering its taste or nutritional value.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Pasteurization is a critical process used to ensure the safety of milk by killing most non-spore-forming pathogens. The Holder method (63°C for 30 minutes) and flash pasteurization (72°C for 15-20 seconds) are commonly used techniques that effectively reduce microbial load while preserving the quality and taste of milk, although some heat-resistant bacteria may survive these processes.

questions.text: Zika virus is transmitted by: ( NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Aedes aegypti

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Aedes aegypti mosquitoes are the primary vectors for the transmission of Zika virus. Effective prevention and control measures involve protecting against mosquito bites through the use of insect repellents, bed nets, and eliminating standing water where mosquitoes breed. Awareness of the risks associated with Zika, particularly for pregnant women, is crucial for preventing infection and its severe consequences.

questions.text: Which virus requires reverse transcriptase PCR for detection? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) RSV

Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Respiratory Syncytial Virus (RSV) is an RNA virus that requires reverse transcription PCR (RT-PCR) to convert its RNA into DNA for detection. RT-PCR is a sensitive method used to detect and quantify RNA viruses by first converting their RNA into complementary DNA (cDNA) using the enzyme reverse transcriptase.
  • • Other Options :
  • • Other Options
  • • Option B. Herpes virus: Herpes viruses are DNA viruses and do not require reverse transcription. They can be detected using standard PCR methods that amplify their DNA directly.
  • • Option B. Herpes virus:
  • • Option C. EBV (Epstein-Barr Virus): Epstein-Barr Virus is a DNA virus and uses standard PCR for detection. Reverse transcription is not necessary for DNA viruses.
  • • Option C. EBV (Epstein-Barr Virus):
  • • Option D. CMV (Cytomegalovirus): Cytomegalovirus is also a DNA virus and can be detected through standard DNA PCR. Reverse transcription is not needed for its detection.
  • • Option D. CMV (Cytomegalovirus):

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ RSV, an RNA virus, requires reverse transcription PCR (RT-PCR) for detection by converting RNA into DNA.

questions.text: A petechial rash is associated with all the following, except? ( INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) Roseola infantum

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Roseola infantum is characterized by a rapid onset of a high fever followed by a rash, but it does not typically present with petechial rashes. In contrast, Zika virus, Kyasanur Forest disease, and West Nile fever can cause petechial rashes as part of their clinical manifestations.

questions.text: A patient presents with suspected dengue fever on the third day of illness. Which of the following investigations is LEAST likely to yield a diagnostic result at this stage? (AIIMS NOV 2016)

options.label: A
options.text: Viral culture and isolation in C6/36 cell line

options.label: B
options.text: ELISA for detection of dengue virus antibodies

questions.correct_answer: B. ELISA for detection of dengue virus antibodies
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • In the acute phase of dengue infection (first 5-6 days), the following tests can be used for diagnosis:
  • • Viral culture and isolation: This method is sensitive but time-consuming, requiring specialized laboratory facilities. It can detect the virus in the early stages of infection. NS1 antigen detection: This test detects a non-structural protein of the dengue virus, which is present in the blood during the early phase of infection (typically within the first week). RT-PCR for dengue virus RNA: This highly sensitive test detects the genetic material of the virus and can provide a rapid diagnosis within the first few days of illness.
  • • Viral culture and isolation: This method is sensitive but time-consuming, requiring specialized laboratory facilities. It can detect the virus in the early stages of infection.
  • • NS1 antigen detection: This test detects a non-structural protein of the dengue virus, which is present in the blood during the early phase of infection (typically within the first week).
  • • RT-PCR for dengue virus RNA: This highly sensitive test detects the genetic material of the virus and can provide a rapid diagnosis within the first few days of illness.
  • • However, ELISA for antibody detection against the dengue virus is not reliable in the early stages of infection. It takes about 5 days for the body to produce detectable levels of IgM antibodies against the dengue virus. Therefore, ELISA would not be a suitable test for diagnosing dengue on the third day of illness.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ ELISA for dengue antibody detection is not a suitable diagnostic test in the early stages of dengue infection (before day 5). Other tests like viral culture, NS1 antigen detection, and RT-PCR are more appropriate for early diagnosis.

questions.text: Which of the following is used for the treatment of paucibacillary leprosy? (AIIMS NOV 2019)
questions.explanation: Ans. C. 3 drugs for 6 months

questions.text: The components of qSOFA score include all except: (AIIMS NOV 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) Increased heart rate

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The sequential organ failure assessment score (SOFA score), previously known as the sepsis-related organ failure assessment score, is used to track a person's status during the stay in an intensive care unit (ICU) to determine the extent of a person's organ function or rate of failure.
  • ➤ The score is based on six different scores, one each for the respiratory, cardiovascular, hepatic, coagulation, renal and neurological systems.
  • ➤ The Quick SOFA Score (quickSOFA or qSOFA) was introduced by the Sepsis-3 group in February 2016 as a simplified version of the SOFA Score as an initial way to identify patients at high risk for poor outcome with an infection.
  • ➤ The score ranges from 0 to 3 points. The presence of 2 or more qSOFA points near the onset of infection was associated with a greater risk of death or prolonged intensive care unit stay.

questions.text: A 45-year-old man arrives at the emergency department, reporting upper abdominal pain that started after consuming a large meal. During the physical examination, there's notable tenderness in the upper abdominal region. Findings from a chest X-ray show an enlargement of the mediastinum and pneumomediastinum. What is the probable diagnosis? (NEET PG 2020)

options.label: D
options.text: Rupture of emphysematous bulla of lung

questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Spontaneous perforation of esophagus

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The clinical scenario is suggestive of spontaneous perforation of the esophagus, also known as Boerhaave's syndrome. It occurs due to vomiting against a closed glottis/cricopharynx, leading to a massive rise in esophageal pressure and subsequent perforation. This typically happens on the left lower wall of the esophagus.
  • • Clinical Features of Spontaneous Perforation of the Esophagus (Boerhaave's Syndrome):
  • • Clinical Features of Spontaneous Perforation of the Esophagus (Boerhaave's Syndrome):
  • • Chest Pain: Sudden and severe pain that may radiate to the back, neck, or abdomen, often exacerbated by swallowing. Vomiting: Severe vomiting that precedes the onset of pain, leading to esophageal rupture. Dyspnea or Shortness of Breath: Due to leakage of air and fluids into the chest cavity, causing pleural effusion or pneumothorax. Subcutaneous Emphysema: Air leaks from the esophagus into the chest wall, causing a characteristic crackling sensation when the skin is palpated. Shock: Severe cases may lead to shock due to sepsis or hypovolemia. Hamman's Sign: A crunching or rasping sound synchronous with the heartbeat, heard over the precordium or left lateral chest wall on auscultation, caused by heartbeats displacing air-filled tissues. Abdominal Pain and Tenderness: Especially if the perforation is near the lower part of the esophagus. Fever: A response to inflammation and infection.
  • • Chest Pain: Sudden and severe pain that may radiate to the back, neck, or abdomen, often exacerbated by swallowing.
  • • Chest Pain:
  • • Vomiting: Severe vomiting that precedes the onset of pain, leading to esophageal rupture.
  • • Vomiting:
  • • Dyspnea or Shortness of Breath: Due to leakage of air and fluids into the chest cavity, causing pleural effusion or pneumothorax.
  • • Dyspnea or Shortness of Breath:
  • • Subcutaneous Emphysema: Air leaks from the esophagus into the chest wall, causing a characteristic crackling sensation when the skin is palpated.
  • • Subcutaneous Emphysema:
  • • Shock: Severe cases may lead to shock due to sepsis or hypovolemia.
  • • Shock:
  • • Hamman's Sign: A crunching or rasping sound synchronous with the heartbeat, heard over the precordium or left lateral chest wall on auscultation, caused by heartbeats displacing air-filled tissues.
  • • Hamman's Sign:
  • • Abdominal Pain and Tenderness: Especially if the perforation is near the lower part of the esophagus.
  • • Abdominal Pain and Tenderness:
  • • Fever: A response to inflammation and infection.
  • • Fever:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Perforation of peptic ulcer: This usually presents with sudden, severe abdominal pain and signs of peritonitis. The diagnosis would typically show free air under the diaphragm on an upright chest X-ray, not mediastinal enlargement and pneumomediastinum.
  • • Option B. Perforation of peptic ulcer:
  • • Option C. Foreign body in esophagus: This condition may cause dysphagia, odynophagia, and localized pain but is less likely to present with mediastinal enlargement and pneumomediastinum unless it leads to perforation.
  • • Option C. Foreign body in esophagus:
  • • Option D. Rupture of emphysematous bulla of lung: This condition can cause sudden chest pain and pneumothorax but does not typically present with pneumomediastinum and is not related to eating or upper abdominal pain.
  • • Option D. Rupture of emphysematous bulla of lung:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Spontaneous perforation of the esophagus (Boerhaave's syndrome) is characterized by severe chest pain, vomiting, dyspnea, subcutaneous emphysema, and pneumomediastinum, often following severe vomiting. This diagnosis should be considered in patients presenting with these symptoms, especially with radiographic evidence of mediastinal enlargement and pneumomediastinum.

questions.text: A 46-year-old male presents to the ER with the acute onset of ataxia. Neurological examination shows loss of pain and temperature sensation from the face on the left side and loss of pain and temperature sensation from the right half of the body. He also has dysarthria, dysphagia, and diminished gag reflex with ptosis, miosis, and anhidrosis on the left. What is the most likely diagnosis? (Neet pg 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans.

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Lateral medullary syndrome (Wallenberg syndrome) is characterized by ipsilateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the face, contralateral loss of pain and temperature sensation in the body, dysarthria, dysphagia, and ipsilateral Horner's syndrome.

questions.text: What is the usual position of the Golgi apparatus in serous acinar cells? ( AIIMS May 2018)
questions.explanation:

questions.text: Which of the following increases in COPD? ( INICET May 2020) FRC TLC VC FEV1/FVC
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 1 and 2

Educational Objective:

questions.text: A lady presents with fever, oral ulcers, photosensitivity, and rashes on her face, as shown below. What is the most likely diagnosis? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. Systemic lupus erythematosus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ When presented with a patient who shows systemic symptoms like fever and oral ulcers in combination with a characteristic facial rash and photosensitivity, Systemic Lupus Erythematosus should be considered a likely diagnosis. Confirmatory diagnosis would require additional clinical and serological criteria, including a positive antinuclear antibody (ANA) test.

References:

  • ↳ Reference - Harrison/Rheumatology/ SLE, Chap 356

questions.text: Meissner corpuscles are present in: (AIIMS Nov 2018)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A. Papillary dermis

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The papillary dermis is the uppermost layer of the dermis, lying directly beneath the epidermis. It is named so because of its projections called dermal papillae that interlock with the rete ridges of the epidermis.
  • • These dermal papillae increase the surface area between the epidermis and dermis, allowing for better nutrient exchange and anchoring. Meissner corpuscles, also known as tactile corpuscles, are located in the papillary dermis, especially in areas sensitive to light touch, such as the fingertips and lips. They are oval-shaped mechanoreceptors that are sensitive to fine touch and low-frequency vibration.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option B. Reticular dermis: The reticular dermis is the deeper and thicker layer of the dermis, located beneath the papillary dermis. It is comprised mainly of dense irregular connective tissue containing collagen and elastin fibers. While it contains other structures like sweat glands, hair follicles, and blood vessels, Meissner corpuscles are not found in this layer.
  • • Option B. Reticular dermis:
  • • Option C. Basal epidermis: The basal epidermis, or stratum basale, is the innermost layer of the epidermis. It consists of a single layer of columnar or cuboidal keratinocytes. These cells are continuously dividing and pushing older cells upwards towards the skin surface. The basal layer also contains melanocytes, which produce the pigment melanin, and Merkel cells, another type of tactile mechanoreceptor. However, Meissner corpuscles are not found in this layer.
  • • Option C. Basal epidermis:
  • • Option D. Stratum lucidum: The stratum lucidum is a thin, clear layer of the epidermis, typically found only in areas of thick skin such as the palms of the hands and the soles of the feet. It lies between the stratum corneum (outermost layer) and the stratum granulosum. The stratum lucidum is made up of dead, flat keratinocytes that have a translucent appearance. Meissner corpuscles are not located in this epidermal layer.
  • • Option D. Stratum lucidum:

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Meissner corpuscles are found in papillary dermis, are enriched in the fingers and toes, and have an unmyelinated nerve terminal that is surrounded by Schwann cells.

questions.text: A 55-year-old immunocompromised patient with a history of acute myeloid leukemia presents with persistent fever, cough, and shortness of breath despite broad-spectrum antibiotics. A chest CT scan reveals multiple nodular infiltrates with halo signs suggestive of fungal infection. The physician orders a serum galactomannan assay to aid in the diagnosis. Which condition is indicated by the presence of galactomannan in the serum?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • The presence of galactomannan in serum is indicative of invasive aspergillosis, a serious fungal infection primarily affecting immunocompromised individuals, such as those with hematologic malignancies or undergoing stem cell transplantation. Galactomannan is a polysaccharide component of the Aspergillus cell wall, released during active fungal growth in the host. Detection of galactomannan in serum or bronchoalveolar lavage (BAL) fluid using enzyme-linked immunosorbent assay (ELISA) is a valuable diagnostic tool for early identification of invasive aspergillosis, allowing timely antifungal treatment.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. Candidiasis : Candidiasis is caused by Candida species, which do not release galactomannan as a component of their cell wall. Diagnosis is usually made by blood cultures, biopsy, or other antigen detection methods specific to Candida, such as beta-D-glucan assays.
  • • Option A. Candidiasis
  • • Option C. Cryptococcosis : Cryptococcosis is caused by Cryptococcus species, and its diagnosis relies on the detection of cryptococcal antigen in blood or cerebrospinal fluid. Galactomannan is not associated with Cryptococcus, and its presence does not indicate this infection.
  • • Option C. Cryptococcosis
  • • Option D. Histoplasmosis : Histoplasmosis is caused by Histoplasma capsulatum, a dimorphic fungus, and its diagnosis typically involves antigen detection in urine or serum, fungal cultures, and histopathological examination. Galactomannan testing is not used in diagnosing histoplasmosis.
  • • Option D. Histoplasmosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The detection of galactomannan in serum or bronchoalveolar lavage fluid is a key diagnostic marker for invasive aspergillosis, especially in immunocompromised patients. This antigen detection test helps in the early diagnosis and management of invasive fungal infections, significantly improving patient outcomes when coupled with prompt antifungal therapy

questions.text: The image below shows the life cycle of a virus. Which of the proteins of the virus act as oncogenes? ( INICET NOV 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) E6, E7

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ E6 and E7 proteins of HPV are the primary oncogenes responsible for the virus's ability to cause cancer. They do this by inactivating key tumor suppressor proteins, p53 and pRb, leading to uncontrolled cell growth and proliferation.
  • ➤ E6 and E7 proteins of HPV are the primary oncogenes responsible for the virus's ability to cause cancer. They do this by inactivating key tumor suppressor proteins, p53 and pRb, leading to uncontrolled cell growth and proliferation.

questions.text: A man with FUO has a job that requires traveling around the world. The bone marrow picture is shown below. Which of the following investigation would be the most appropriate in this case? (INICET MAY 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) rk 39 antigen test, Leishmaniasis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective
  • ➤ The presence of macrophages with intracellular Leishmania donovani bodies in the bone marrow is diagnostic for leishmaniasis. The rk 39 antigen test is a rapid and reliable method for confirming visceral leishmaniasis.

questions.text: A 3-week-old infant is brought to OPD with complaints of cough and sore throat. The mother reports that the infant develops a paroxysm of cough followed by apnea. Blood investigations reveal total leucocyte count to be >50,000 cells/L. Which of the following drugs is appropriate for this patient? (NEET PG 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Azithromycin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For infants presenting with pertussis (whooping cough), characterized by paroxysmal cough and elevated leukocyte count, the drug of choice is azithromycin.

questions.text: Testosterone helps in the development of various organs in the fetus. Which of the following stimulates its production? (NEET PG 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) HCG from placenta

Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • HCG from placenta : HCG (human chorionic gonadotropin) from the placenta stimulates the production of testosterone in the male fetus. HCG released from the placenta is the initial stimulus for testosterone production in the male fetus. Later by the eighth week of gestation, fetal pituitary LH (luteinizing hormone) stimulates the Leydig cells of the testes to produce testosterone. Sex differentiation of the embryo depends on the Y chromosome, which contains the testis-determining gene called the SRY (sex-determining region on Y) gene. In a genetically male embryo (46, XY), the gonad is converted into testis under the influence of this gene. Female development (Mullerian ducts) occurs in the absence of this gene.
  • • HCG from placenta : HCG (human chorionic gonadotropin) from the placenta stimulates the production of testosterone in the male fetus. HCG released from the placenta is the initial stimulus for testosterone production in the male fetus. Later by the eighth week of gestation, fetal pituitary LH (luteinizing hormone) stimulates the Leydig cells of the testes to produce testosterone. Sex differentiation of the embryo depends on the Y chromosome, which contains the testis-determining gene called the SRY (sex-determining region on Y) gene. In a genetically male embryo (46, XY), the gonad is converted into testis under the influence of this gene. Female development (Mullerian ducts) occurs in the absence of this gene.
  • • HCG from placenta
  • • HCG (human chorionic gonadotropin) from the placenta stimulates the production of testosterone in the male fetus. HCG released from the placenta is the initial stimulus for testosterone production in the male fetus. Later by the eighth week of gestation, fetal pituitary LH (luteinizing hormone) stimulates the Leydig cells of the testes to produce testosterone. Sex differentiation of the embryo depends on the Y chromosome, which contains the testis-determining gene called the SRY (sex-determining region on Y) gene. In a genetically male embryo (46, XY), the gonad is converted into testis under the influence of this gene. Female development (Mullerian ducts) occurs in the absence of this gene.
  • • HCG (human chorionic gonadotropin) from the placenta stimulates the production of testosterone in the male fetus.
  • • HCG released from the placenta is the initial stimulus for testosterone production in the male fetus.
  • • Later by the eighth week of gestation, fetal pituitary LH (luteinizing hormone) stimulates the Leydig cells of the testes to produce testosterone.
  • • Sex differentiation of the embryo depends on the Y chromosome, which contains the testis-determining gene called the SRY (sex-determining region on Y) gene.
  • • In a genetically male embryo (46, XY), the gonad is converted into testis under the influence of this gene.
  • • Female development (Mullerian ducts) occurs in the absence of this gene.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A. LH from maternal pituitary : Maternal LH does not play a role in fetal testosterone production. The fetal pituitary gland, not the maternal pituitary, influences testosterone production later in gestation.
  • • Option A. LH from maternal pituitary
  • • Option C. Inhibin from corpus luteum : Inhibin is involved in the regulation of FSH and does not stimulate testosterone production. It primarily acts to provide feedback inhibition to the anterior pituitary gland to control FSH levels.
  • • Option C. Inhibin from corpus luteum
  • • Option D. GnRH from fetal hypothalamus : GnRH (gonadotropin-releasing hormone) from the fetal hypothalamus plays a role in stimulating the fetal pituitary to release LH and FSH, but it is not the initial trigger for testosterone production in the fetus.
  • • Option D. GnRH from fetal hypothalamus

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ HCG from the placenta is the initial stimulus for testosterone production in the male fetus.
  • ➤ Ref: Page 103, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition
  • ➤ Ref: Page 103, Williams Obstetrics 26 th edition

questions.text: A 58-year-old diabetic man presents to the emergency department with facial swelling, black eschar on the palate, and blurred vision in his right eye. He has a recent history of sinusitis that has rapidly progressed despite treatment. Imaging reveals extensive sinus involvement and orbital extension. A fungal infection is suspected, and a biopsy confirms mucormycosis. Which component of the fungal cell wall is absent in this fungal infection, differentiating it from other common fungal pathogens?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation:
  • • Mucormycosis is caused by fungi of the order Mucorales, including species such as Rhizopus and Mucor, which are characterized by the absence or minimal presence of Beta-1, 3-D-glucan in their cell walls. Beta-1, 3-D-glucan is a major polysaccharide present in the cell walls of most other pathogenic fungi, such as Candida and Aspergillus. Its absence in mucormycosis is clinically significant because diagnostic tests like the Beta-D-glucan assay, which detects this component, will not identify infections caused by Mucorales. This distinguishing feature is crucial for differentiating mucormycosis from other invasive fungal infections.
  • • Other Options
  • • Other Options
  • • Option A. Beta-1, 6-D-glucan : This component is found in the cell walls of many fungi, including Candida and Aspergillus, but its presence or absence is not a defining characteristic of mucormycosis. It is not specific to Mucorales and does not differentiate them from other fungi.
  • • Option A. Beta-1, 6-D-glucan
  • • Option C. Galactomannan : Galactomannan is a polysaccharide found in the cell walls of Aspergillus species and is commonly used in the diagnosis of invasive aspergillosis. However, it is not a component of Mucorales and is irrelevant in the context of mucormycosis, though its absence does not specifically define these fungi.
  • • Option C. Galactomannan
  • • Option D. Alpha-glucan : Alpha-glucan is another structural polysaccharide found in some fungal species but is not specifically absent in mucormycosis. Its presence or absence is not used as a key differentiating factor in diagnosing mucormycosis compared to other fungal infections.
  • • Option D. Alpha-glucan

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mucormycosis, caused by fungi of the order Mucorales, is distinguished by the absence or minimal presence of Beta-1, 3-D-glucan in its cell wall. This absence affects the accuracy of common fungal diagnostic tests, necessitating alternative diagnostic strategies for accurate identification and treatment of mucormycosis

questions.text: Which of the following conditions is the Banana sign on USG associated with? (INICET MAY 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Spina bifida

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The "Banana sign" on ultrasound is specifically associated with spina bifida and represents the abnormal shape of the cerebellar vermis. It is a critical ultrasound finding suggestive of spina bifida and should be carefully evaluated alongside other signs such as the "Lemon sign," which depicts an abnormal skull shape resembling a lemon, also indicative of neural tube defects like spina bifida.

questions.text: A 73-year-old diabetic, hypertensive woman underwent a cardiac biopsy. Her histology image with special stain is as shown below. What is the diagnosis? (INICET NOV 2023)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C) Restrictive cardiomyopathy

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ In restrictive cardiomyopathy, the key histological feature is myocardial fibrosis leading to stiffening of the heart muscle, which impacts its ability to fill properly during diastole, though systolic function might be preserved.

questions.text: What is the type of necrosis seen in the vessel wall of a patient with polyarteritis nodosa? (NEET PG 2019)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Fibrinoid necrosis

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Fibrinoid necrosis is seen in the following conditions:
  • ➤ SLE Libman-sacks endocarditis Arthus reaction Serum sickness Polyarteritis nodosa Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis Malignant hypertension
  • ➤ SLE
  • ➤ Libman-sacks endocarditis
  • ➤ Arthus reaction
  • ➤ Serum sickness
  • ➤ Polyarteritis nodosa
  • ➤ Polyarteritis nodosa
  • ➤ Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis
  • ➤ Post-streptococcal glomerulonephritis
  • ➤ Malignant hypertension

questions.text: Phospholipase C acts via which of the following G protein-coupled receptors? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Gq

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Phospholipase C (PLC) is activated by Gq-coupled receptors, which in turn generate the second messengers IP3 and DAG, leading to various downstream effects, including the mobilization of calcium ions from intracellular stores.

questions.text: A young man sustained a scorpion sting 2 hours ago. On examination, his blood pressure is 104/ 55 mm Hg; Heart Rate 72 beats/minute, and respiratory rate 32 breaths/ minute. He also complains of breathlessness. Which of the following is the preferred drug for management of this patient? ( INICET Nov 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. C. Prazosin

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Prazosin is the preferred drug for managing the symptoms of a scorpion sting, as it counteracts the effects of catecholamines released due to the venom, providing relief from hypertension and pulmonary edema. Other drugs listed do not directly address the primary pathophysiological effects of a scorpion sting.

questions.text: A 35-year-old woman presents to the clinic with a persistent dry cough, sore throat, and mild fever for the past 10 days. She has no significant past medical history. Physical examination shows clear lung fields, and a chest X-ray reveals patchy infiltrates indicative of atypical pneumonia. The clinician suspects Mycoplasma pneumoniae infection. Which class of antibiotics should be avoided due to Mycoplasma's inherent resistance?
questions.explanation:
Explanation:

  • • Explanation
  • • Mycoplasma pneumoniae is inherently resistant to beta-lactam antibiotics because it lacks a cell wall, which is the target of these drugs. Beta-lactams, such as penicillins and cephalosporins, inhibit the synthesis of peptidoglycan, a crucial cell wall component in bacteria. Since Mycoplasma does not possess a cell wall, beta-lactam antibiotics have no effect. The treatment for Mycoplasma infections involves antibiotics that act on protein synthesis or DNA replication, such as macrolides, tetracyclines, or fluoroquinolones.
  • • Other Options:
  • • Other Options:
  • • Option A) Aminoglycosides : Aminoglycosides inhibit bacterial protein synthesis by binding to the 30S ribosomal subunit. While not commonly used for Mycoplasma, they are not inherently ineffective against it based on the absence of a cell wall.
  • • Option A) Aminoglycosides
  • • Option B) Sulfonamides : Sulfonamides act by inhibiting folic acid synthesis in bacteria. Mycoplasma does not inherently resist sulfonamides, but these drugs are not the primary choice for treating Mycoplasma infections due to their variable efficacy.
  • • Option B) Sulfonamides
  • • Option D) Glycopeptides : Glycopeptides, like vancomycin, inhibit cell wall synthesis by binding to D-alanyl-D-alanine termini of peptidoglycan. While effective against gram-positive organisms, they are ineffective against Mycoplasma due to the absence of a cell wall.
  • • Option D) Glycopeptides

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Mycoplasma pneumoniae lacks a cell wall, rendering it inherently resistant to beta-lactam antibiotics, which target cell wall synthesis. Effective treatment options include macrolides, tetracyclines, and fluoroquinolones, which target bacterial protein synthesis or DNA replication instead.

questions.text: A pap smear taken from a patient revealed hyperchromatic nuclei, irregular nuclear borders, and low maturation index involving the whole thickness but did not breach the basement membrane. What is the diagnosis? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. A) Dysplasia

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ Dysplasia is characterized by abnormal cellular features such as pleomorphism, hyperchromatic nuclei, increased mitotic figures, and a high nuclear-to-cytoplasmic ratio. It involves the entire thickness of the epithelium without breaching the basement membrane, distinguishing it from carcinoma, which involves invasion beyond the basement membrane.

questions.text: A patient presents to the hospital with complaints of abdominal pain. A stool examination was done, and it showed the presence of the organism shown in image A. The body has segments broader than the length. Which of the eggs shown in column B corresponds to this organism? (INICET MAY 2022)
questions.explanation:
Ans. D) 4

questions.text: A 20-year-old male came to the emergency after sustaining an injury and was given 0.25% bupivacaine for regional anesthesia. A few minutes later, he became unresponsive and pulseless. What would be the ideal management? (NEET PG 2021)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B. CPR & 20% IV Intralipid

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ For local anesthetic systemic toxicity (LAST), immediate management includes starting CPR and administering 20% intravenous lipid emulsion (Intralipid) therapy. This approach helps to rapidly reduce the toxic effects of the local anesthetic on the cardiovascular and central nervous systems.

questions.text: Identify the most probable age of the child under POCSO (Protection of Children from Sexual Offences) Act by looking at the X-ray below:(NEET PG 2020)
questions.explanation:
Ans. B) 7 years

Educational Objective:

  • ➤ Educational Objective:
  • ➤ The x-ray shown in the image suggests the age of the child to be 7 years as the x-ray does not have the Pisiform bone. Pisiform bone ossifies by the age of 13.
  • ➤ The x-ray shown in the image suggests the age of the child to be 7 years as the x-ray does not have the Pisiform bone.
  • ➤ Pisiform bone ossifies by the age of 13.
